awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Interfacing Remote Quantum Dot Nanostructures by Resonant Light Scattering
awd_abstract_narration:
****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
The goal of this project is the demonstration of an elementary quantum interface between two spatially separated solid-state quantum systems by using resonant light scattering, with the purpose of producing entanglement. It will be shown that InAs quantum dot nanostructures, with outstanding quantum-coherent optical properties, can generate single photons suitably-tailored for this purpose. In a phased approach indistinguishable photons from remotely located quantum dots will be produced using monochromatic continuous-wave, multichromatic and finally pulsed laser excitation. A tomographic analysis will be implemented to verify the generation of entanglement once a sufficiently large degree of two-photon interference has been obtained. Unique advantages of this approach lie in the relaxed requirements for frequency matching of photons as well as in reduced dephasing when compared to non-resonant excitation. A quantitative understanding of phenomena expected to hinder the manifestation of entanglement, in particular spectral diffusion, will be sought out. This research which lies at the boundary of condensed matter physics, nanoscience, and quantum optics will be an invaluable multidisciplinary experience for graduate and undergraduate students. A comprehensive outreach effort is designed to disseminate excitement and knowledge to a larger public by organizing professional development for teachers, high school senior student projects, campus tours, and classroom demonstrations. 

****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Quantum mechanical methods to encode, process and transmit information are expected to replace one day the current classical architecture of information technology. Quantum mechanical states produced by or encoded in condensed matter systems are particularly attractive to achieve this goal because of their intrinsic scalability and compatibility with existing micro and nanofabrication technology. The goal of this project is to use resonant light scattering from laser-driven InAs quantum dot nanostructures for the purpose of creating quantum mechanical superposition states between remotely located entities. The resulting quantum entanglement, in which the measurement of the state of one entity determines with certainty the outcome of the measurement of the state of the other entity, is a central resource in quantum information science. This project provides a previously unexplored route to entanglement in solids, relying on a resonant light generation mechanism that produces indistinguishable photons. Combining unique expertise from materials science, quantum optics and photonics engineering, this work will offer hands-on research experience to undergraduate and graduate students in a multidisciplinary environment. The project includes a comprehensive plan to make this knowledge accessible to a larger pubic, via professional development for teachers, high school senior project student participation, campus tours, and classroom demonstrations.

por.por_cntn:
This project has investigated the properties of light resonantly scattered by individual quantum dot nanostructures, i.e., light generated by a nanostructure at the same wavelength as that of an incident laser beam. Its overarching goal was the production of quantum entanglement, which confers constituents of a quantum system a relationship that cannot be described classically, even when these constituents are spatially separated, forming the basis of quantum communication protocols. A major potential benefit of deriving nonclassical states through a process of resonant light scattering as opposed to other methods is an inherent simplicity: the light-matter interaction at its core is that of a monochromatic laser coupling to a two-state quantum system. A series of experiments with indium arsenide quantum dots—islands of hundreds of thousands of atoms in a host crystal of larger energy gap (gallium arsenide)—as the two-state quantum system were carried out as part of this project. Under cryogenic conditions (-452°F), basic spectral and temporal properties were first characterized which showed that the nanostructures under study nearly behaved as quantum two-level systems apart from an intrinsic environmental noise leading to “spectral diffusion” and phonon interactions. Further characterization revealed that spectral filtering, following recent theoretical proposals, could induce photon pair generation of the kind needed for quantum entanglement. Measurements have explored a wide parameter space of excitation conditions (continuous and pulsed) and detection conditions (one photon, two-photon, and three photon correlation detection). The project has provided support for five graduate students working toward a doctorate degree in Applied Physics, including for students from traditionally under-represented groups. It resulted in nine journal article publications, two of which were selected as ``editors’ suggestion” in the Physical Reviews. The project has involved numerous undergraduate students and as a broader effort created a set of laboratory know-how tutorial videos for effectively disseminating knowledge pertaining to the research project, with a combined youtube views in excess of 70,000 (http://faculty.cas.usf.edu/mullera/Solid_State_Quantum_Optics_Lab_USF/Educational.html). Scientific highlights from the project include the first of its kind measurement of the “two-photon spectrum” of resonance fluorescence from a single quantum dot [Phys. Rev. B 91, 195125 (2015)] and the first measurement of “Franson interference” from a two-level quantum system [Phys. Rev. Lett. 118, 030501 (2017).]
